awd_titl_txt: Text Recycling in Scientific Research Writing
awd_abstract_narration:
Often called "self-plagiarism," text recycling occurs frequently in scientific writing. Over the past decade, increasing numbers of scientific journals have begun using plagiarism detection software to screen submitted manuscripts. As a result, large numbers of cases of text recycling are being identified, yet there is no consensus on what constitutes ethically acceptable practice. Text recycling is thus an increasingly important and controversial ethical issue in scientific communication. However, little actual research has been conducted on text recycling and it is rarely addressed in the ethical training of researchers or in scientific writing textbooks or websites. To promote the ethical and appropriate use of text recycling, this project will be conducted in two phases: In Phase 1, the researchers will investigate the ethical, practical, and legal aspects of text recycling as relevant for professional researchers, students, and publishers. In Phase 2, the investigators will produce educational materials and develop model language for text recycling guidelines and author-publisher contracts that can be adapted by educational institutions, research organizations, and publishers.

This project is a multi-institutional, multidisciplinary investigation of text recycling, the reuse of material from one?s previous work in a new manuscript. In Phase 1, the researchers will investigate questions such as these: What do expert researchers, students, and others involved in scientific communication believe to be appropriate practice, and why? Where is there a clear consensus among experts and where is there substantive disagreement? How often do professional scientists actually recycle material, and in what ways? Under what circumstances does text recycling violate publisher contracts or copyright laws? One facet of this research will involve interviewing and surveying experienced STEM faculty, students, journal editors, and others regarding the ethics of text recycling. A second facet will analyze a corpus of published scientific papers to investigate how researchers recycle text in practice and how this has changed over time. The third facet involves analyzing publisher contracts to better understand the rights of publishers and authors regarding text recycling and to assess their legal validity. In Phase 2, the investigators will use findings from Phase 1 to develop, test, and disseminate two kinds of materials: The first are web and print based instructional materials for STEM students (and others new to STEM research) explaining the ethical, legal, and practical issues involved with text recycling, as well as accompanying documents for faculty, administrators, and librarians. The second are model policies and guidelines for text recycling that address appropriate practice in both academic and professional settings. The investigators will obtain feedback on drafts of these materials from potential users and revise them accordingly, after which they will be disseminated.

por.por_cntn:
Reusing material from one’s own previously written documents in a new document is called “text recycling” (AKA “self-plagiarism”). Scientists often have a legitimate need to recycle text, especially in two common situations: One is reusing unpublished materials—such as details from a research poster presented at a conference—in a research article on the same study for publication. The other is when they are writing a research article on a new study that builds on their previously published work; in these cases, there are often details such as descriptions of experimental methods or theoretical background that are the same from one study to the next. While such uses of text recycling are usually legitimate, some researchers go beyond these uses—republishing the actual findings from one of their prior studies in a deceptive attempt to inflate their publication output, a practice that is unethical and often illegal.

While the recycling of unpublished materials has been largely uncontroversial, the recycling of previously published material has been the subject of considerable debate and confusion. Unlike other matters related to the responsible conduct of research, the ethics and legality of text recycling are complex and vary considerably based on context. On the ethical side, the main concerns are whether editors or readers are being deceived by the inclusion of previously published material in the new publication and whether authors are getting undeserved promotions. On the legal side, the legality of any particular instance text recycling depends on whether it infringes copyrights or violates an author’s signed publishing agreement. 

We applied for this NSF grant in 2017 to start the Text Recycling Research Project (TRRP) because there was a clear need for substantive research into the ethical and legal aspects of text reuse and no authoritative sources which scientists and publishers could consult. 

Now, at the end of the grant period, we have published over a dozen research papers and essays on our research, addressing various ethical, practical, and legal aspects of text recycling. We have drawn on our extensive research to produce a unique set of resources on text recycling in the research environment including educational materials, best practice guidelines, a model text recycling policy for publishers, and a model policy and guide for faculty regarding text reuse in the classroom context. While these resources were developed specifically to address the needs of authors, editors, and teachers in STEM fields, they will also be valuable for researchers in other fields, as well as university librarians and research integrity officers. 

To ensure the validity and usefulness of these materials, all TRRP documents have been heavily vetted by the TRRP Advisory Board. The Board’s members have expertise spanning the range of research ethics and scholarly publishing including officers with the Committee on Publication Ethics (COPE) and Council of Science Editors (CSE), heads of research ethics offices at leading for-profit and university presses and federal research agencies.

Our resources have already influenced or been adopted by a wide range of publishers and research agencies, both in the U.S. and worldwide. For example, leading scientific journals including PNAS (Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences) and PLOS now ask authors to consult our Best Practices, and leading medical journals such as the British Medical Journal and Anesthesiology have revised their policies based on our work. Similarly, the National Institutes of Health Intramural Research office now includes our guidance in their training materials for researchers. In 2021, the groundbreaking work of the TRRP was covered by Science, one of the world’s leading scientific journals. 

All TRRP publications and resources are available free of charge at textrecycling.org.
